comments.body:
running from master, here are the calls to get resource prefixes:
```
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"", Resource:"configMaps"}=configmaps
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"", Resource:"endpoints"}=services/endpoints
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"", Resource:"events"}=events
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"", Resource:"limitRanges"}=limitranges
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"", Resource:"namespaces"}=namespaces
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"", Resource:"nodes"}=minions
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"", Resource:"persistentVolumeClaims"}=persistentvolumeclaims
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"", Resource:"persistentVolumes"}=persistentvolumes
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"", Resource:"podTemplates"}=podtemplates
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"", Resource:"pods"}=pods
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"", Resource:"replicationControllers"}=controllers
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"", Resource:"resourceQuotas"}=resourcequotas
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"", Resource:"secrets"}=secrets
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"", Resource:"serviceAccounts"}=serviceaccounts
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"", Resource:"services"}=services/specs
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"apps", Resource:"statefulsets"}=statefulsets
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"autoscaling", Resource:"horizontalpodautoscalers"}=horizontalpodautoscalers
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"batch", Resource:"jobs"}=jobs
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"certificates.k8s.io", Resource:"certificatesigningrequests"}=certificatesigningrequests
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"extensions", Resource:"daemonsets"}=daemonsets
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"extensions", Resource:"deployments"}=deployments
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"extensions", Resource:"horizontalpodautoscalers"}=horizontalpodautoscalers
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"extensions", Resource:"ingresses"}=ingress
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"extensions", Resource:"jobs"}=jobs
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"extensions", Resource:"networkpolicies"}=networkpolicies
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"extensions", Resource:"podsecuritypolicy"}=podsecuritypolicy
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"extensions", Resource:"replicasets"}=replicasets
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"extensions", Resource:"thirdpartyresources"}=thirdpartyresources
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"policy", Resource:"poddisruptionbudgets"}=poddisruptionbudgets
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"rbac.authorization.k8s.io", Resource:"clusterrolebindings"}=clusterrolebindings
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"rbac.authorization.k8s.io", Resource:"clusterroles"}=clusterroles
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"rbac.authorization.k8s.io", Resource:"rolebindings"}=rolebindings
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"rbac.authorization.k8s.io", Resource:"roles"}=roles
ResourcePrefix: schema.GroupResource{Group:"storage.k8s.io", Resource:"storageclasses"}=storageclasses
```
Why isn't this a part of `overrides`?

Having customizable defaults and overrides separate (like in this PR) is actually cleanest, IMO. Otherwise the caller will have to figure out if the user's flags imply a default change. If they're split like that, we can leave the code interpreting the flags in genericapiserver.
minion -> node rename: 2.5 years and counting

comments.body: How do we prove we don't regress on old clusters here?  Will 1.3 -> 1.4 deployment catch us.

> How do we prove we don't regress on old clusters here? Will 1.3 -> 1.4 deployment catch us.

I had to find these manually based on code inspection.  Going forward, everyone will be using their resources, to-lowered.  I would suggest that for an etcd3 migration, we consider changing directories to subdivide by API group.

I'm confused here.
In etcd, string are just immutable representation of []byte.
Why do we need to base64-encode it again?

/cc @xiang90
for etcd2 yes. etcd2 only accepts json. json string cannot contain random bytes, you have to base64 it.
question: does it mean that we will have migration to protobufs in etcd for free?

Yes, once the storage type is set registries will start replacing values
that are written with proto.  So the same as a version upgrade - read /
write all values.

On Thu, May 5, 2016 at 4:37 AM, Wojciech Tyczynski <notifications@github.com

> wrote:

> > -       glog.V(4).Infof("Wrapping the underlying binary storage serializer with a base64 encoding for etcd2")

comments.body: Add `var _ StorageFactory := &DefaultStorageFactory{}` to ensure that DefaultStorageFactory implements StorageFactory interface.

> Should be public?

Doesn't need to be.  Prefer to keep it private until we really need it exposed.
